text: In “How to Be an Antiracist,” Ibram X. Kendi argues that we should think of “racist” not as a pejorative but as a simple, widely encompassing term of description. https://t.co/edw9IOHitD

name: NewYorker
text: “We’re just coming to grips with two decades of overmilitarization of our foreign policy,” one advisor said. “It may now be time to be concerned about overmilitarization of our domestic policy.” https://t.co/FmnBjqQa6U

name: NewYorker
text: Millennia later, the plague of Athens reminds us that the legacy of the world’s first democracy contains within it a cautionary tale: the failure of democratic society to cope with a lethal epidemic. https://t.co/1FyEy4meTf

name: NewYorker
text: The live-at-home approach suits Norah Jones, @Paul_R_Elie writes. It foregrounds her directness and natural musicianship, reminding us that she is a truly great singer and a stylish pianist. https://t.co/HeahrU6Mv9

text: On Angela Merkel's rise from brilliant student to political powerhouse. #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/6ZqHXc8QP0

text: The artist and media critic Alexandra Bell revises biased news coverage, exposing racism that hides in plain sight—sometimes on the front page. https://t.co/YKd1Od6F4U

name: NewYorker
text: As tuberculosis shaped modernism, so COVID-19 and our collective experience of staying inside for months on end will influence architecture’s near future, @chaykak writes. https://t.co/GwISo2QoK6

name: NewYorker
text: Each chapter of Korean history has produced films of startling poise, creativity, and insight. Here are 10 of the best of them, now free to watch on YouTube. https://t.co/ugeJc7YSVx

name: NewYorker
text: “All that can save you now is your confrontation with your own history," James Baldwin said, addressing white Americans, in 1968. "[It] is not your past, but your present." https://t.co/QURRIpVGVX

text: Spike Lee’s new film, “Da 5 Bloods,” pulls the traumas of black men’s experiences of the Vietnam War out of obscurity and puts them in the forefront of political consciousness. https://t.co/rHEMga2MQG

text: The Supreme Court’s ruling on DACA does not prevent President Trump from trying to cancel the program again; he’ll just need to start from scratch, and offer a more plausible justification for doing so. https://t.co/qjPwXXzX7w

text: The writer, cook, and artist Tunde Wey discusses his recent essay, “Don’t Bail Out the Restaurant Industry,” and his radical vision for a more equitable culinary world. https://t.co/LMpIidhCCV

text: In an Arkansas penitentiary, 956 people have tested positive for the coronavirus. Rachel Aviv spoke with more than 40 of the men who are imprisoned there. https://t.co/XTyGEunWSt
